topics.body:
"@SquiggyBomb":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5456bcb863687248445c0200#post_5456bcb863687248445c0200
What do those things the Japs put on the end of names even mean?
topics.author: 52f0834d63687261cba90300

topics.body:
"@Albus Fahrenheits":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5456bd60636872715daa0000#post_5456bd60636872715daa0000

They're honorifics. "Here's the condensed version":https://www.google.com/url?q=http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JapaneseHonorifics&sa=U&ei=nL1WVJavOZajyATYhYKgAg&ved=0CAcQFjAC&client=internal-uds-cse&usg=AFQjCNHSWWTr8SVftXS4Pv0S2JsEotpPZg
topics.author: 4fdfbf92945b7075d50036e4

topics.body:
"@Albus Fahrenheits":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5456bd60636872715daa0000#post_5456bd60636872715daa0000
They're honorifics. They're meant to show respect and etiquette.
_San_ is the most neutral one. You use it when you aren't familiar with it.
_Kun_ is a term for people younger than you or friends. It's normally used for males.
_Chan_ is the same but normally used for females, young children, and pets.
_Sama_ is used to instill high respect or regard.
topics.author: 4fde4618945b700aa0002fff
